posts.content:

David

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: For me, it is now easier to make a new build than to search. I want to try to talk you out of Thundering Rage. It is not very useful, and not worth the trouble. I need more information: Dev Crit would be easy to add, and EDR a little bit harder, but doable. What about your weapon? Sword-and-board, two-hander, or dual-wield? Martial weapon or exotic? How about 2 weapons, sword-and-board

The issue will be the same as with most pure fighter builds... horrible Will save.  That's means you'll get dominated in a heartbeat vs. any run-of-the-mill mage.  CoT, pally or BG is near essential for a boost.  Depending on those short-term Clarity pots as a panacea is pretty much useless because the most standard mage NPC AI will dispel as soon as you try to set a buff.  Taunt is useful but chances are, you'll be dealing with artillery magic way beyond the range any taunt can reach.

And I agree with Empyre's earlier comment about Thundering Rage.  Not worth investing a feat unless you have plenty to spare.  Epic Intimidate and Epic Taunt are just two of many more important optimizations to focus on before an extra 2d6 damage on a crit.

Makes me suspect you haven't played against any of the more contemporary and advanced creature AIs and encounters.  Figure on at least 2-3 spellcasters in each one.

While you are using rounds to quaff pots, one of the other invisible mages to the right or left will dominate your barb for a duration easily long enough to dispatch your toon.  A quality AI would never allow any warrior to get within melee range of its casters.  That's why they script those NPCs to spam invis and GS all the time.  For PvP, forget it.  Low will means death to any average arcanist.   You are familiar with a spell called Time Stop, right?

Don't judge the effectiveness of your tactics against vanilla resources.  They won't work the moment you venture into more aggressive environments.

Generally, SP content spends little time implementing advanced AIs like you'll see in server play.  They spend most of their efforts on story, immersion, innovation and eye candy so you can essentially build common builds and progress adequately.  In SP modules, they usually create encounters using one or 2 major threats with a mob of pedestrian minions.  Servers will create encounters of mixtures of several high-level caster types, clerics and mages (and yes, they often take turns casting Time Stop, Domination, IGMS and Bigbys) augmented by a dozen or more melee and archer attacks by high-steath NPCs.  And the undead encounters are tougher yet with all the special attacks like death gaze and ability/level drain by a race that is immune to just about everything.

Since this topic arose from a player that seeks build advice for a high magic PW regularly, all my comments were directed towards that sort of gameplay.

As a rule of thumb, builds and build concepts you see posted by guild members assume they will be used for on-line non-roleplay gaming unless otherwise indicated.  Typically, SP players will use one of the optimized builds posted here or in the legacy archive and then tweak them slightly to adapt to the constraints of the module or series.

TBH, we build predominantly powerbuilds for PvM.  PvP builds are an entirely different sort of build that focuses on dominating specific types of builds like against DevCrit, hi-stealth HiPS, hi-DR tanks, high-mage, SR monks, etc.  No single build will fare equally well against all sorts of dueler builds.

One thing you might like to do to test your own ideas is to install a trainer like The Halls of Advanced Training (it's just a small, fast-loading module).  It allows you to adjust the size and challenge rating of encounters, randomly throwing out different mixes of creatures.  It won't really cover all the bases (like multi-mage spell spamming or death cage matches), but can create much more challenging tests than most SP content.  I had to build my own trainer to mimic the sorts of encounters I was facing on the competitive servers but that was more to discover strategies to survive them than create an invulnerable, deadly build.
